Problem:
Consider a system defined by the function \\( z(t) = wt \\) where \\( w \\) is a complex number with real and imaginary parts. We introduce a linear operator \\( L \\) that takes the form \\( L(z) = \\int_{0}^{T} e^{-st} z(t) dt \\), where \\( s \\) is a complex constant and \\( T \\) is a finite time.

If \\( z(t) \\) is transformed by \\( L \\) initially at t = 0 and then evolved over time up to \\( T \\), will \\( L(z)(T) \\) be identical to applying \\( L \\) directly on \\( z(t) = wt \\) up to \\( T \\) without first evaluating \\( L(z)(0) \\)?
Explanation: The linear transformation by \\( L \\) when applied initially or at any subsequent time up to \\( T \\) essentially computes the same integral over the interval from 0 to \\( T \\). This is because \\( L \\) acts linearly and time-invariantly across the entire range specified, thus yielding the same result regardless of when it's computed.
